children.name: the direction in which sb/sth faces or moves
course
children.definition: the planned direction taken by a boat or plane to reach a place : hướng đi, hướng bay
examples: change course
The planechanged courseto avoid the storm.
The pilot avoided a collision bychangingcourse.
The captain decided to change the ship’s course to avoid the storm.
hold the course(= travelling in the same direction as planned ).
She tightened the mainsail whileholding the course
on/off coursefollowing the correct or incorrect course đúng / sai hướng đi
Investigators say the plane was over 800 miles off course when it crashed.
The ship wasblown off course.
The aircraft was almost ten miles off course.

children.name: direction
children.definition: the way sb/sth moves, faces, or is aimed : hướng
examples: Whichdirectiondid theygo in?
in the right/wrong direction
We’re going in the right direction now - I can see the main road up ahead.
in the opposite direction
Bill marched off angrily in the opposite direction.
from opposite directions
Tornadoes usually form when rising warm, moist air rotates, as winds from opposite directions collide.
in the direction of sth
The suspects were last seen heading in the direction of Miami.
in sb’s direction
Tony glanced in her direction and their eyes met.
The girls pointedin the opposite direction.
On seeing me, Mauricechanged directionand went along the wharf instead.
As shots rang out, the crowd ran screamingin all directions.
from the direction of sth
There was a loud scream from the direction of the children’s pool.
in a southerly/easterly etc direction
Continue in a southerly direction until you reach the road.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually usewhich way ...?when asking where something is rather than using the noundirection:
Whichdirectiondid they go in?➔Which waydid they go? | Whichdirectionis north?➔Which wayis north?
go in a directionI can give you a lift if you're going in my direction.
move/head in a directionWe followed the other passengers heading in the direction of passport control.
look/glance in a directionShe looked in the direction that Jeremy was pointing.
face (in) a directionThe men were facing the direction from which they expected the attack.
change direction(= start to go in a different direction )Suddenly the birds changed direction.
the right/wrong directionAre you sure this is the right direction for Shipton?
the opposite directionThe car crashed into a truck that was coming in the opposite direction.
a southerly/westerly etc directionA strong wind was blowing from an easterly direction.
in each/every direction(alsoin all directions)At the top of the tower there are splendid views in every direction.
in both directionsThe traffic in both directions on the motorway wasn't moving at all.
in different directionsThey said goodbye and walked off in different directions.
in the general direction of something(= approximately where something is )He pointed in the general direction of the village.
in a clockwise/anticlockwise direction(= like or unlike the movement of the hands of a clock )All movement on a roundabout is in a clockwise direciton.
a sense of direction(= the ability to judge which way you should be going )Do you have a good sense of direction?
the direction of movement/travel/flow etcIt was hard work rowing against the direction of flow.

children.name: way
children.definition: the general direction in which sb/sth is moving, is aimed etc: lối, hướng
examples: The bear went that way - you can see its tracks in the snow.
It is important to consider which way the house faces, as that determines how much sun it gets.
Which wayis north?
Walkthis way.
A big Mercedes was comingthe other way(= from the opposite direction ).
He left the house, looking carefully both ways.
the right/wrong way
Are you sure we’re going the right way? I don’t remember seeing that church before.

children.name: face
children.definition: to be opposite someone or something, or to be looking or pointing in a particular direction : hướng về, đối mặt
examples: The terrace faces towards the sea
Their houses face each other across the street.
The two men stood facing each other, smiling.
When heturned to faceher, he seemed annoyed.
Lunch is served on the terrace facing the sea.
face north/east etc
The dining room faces east.
south-facing/west-facing etc
a south-facing garden

children.name: look
children.definition: if a building, structure, etc looks in a particular direction, it faces that direction : nhìn ra
examples: The garden looks south.
This window looks out onto the lake.
The cabin looks east, so we get the morning sun.

children.name: lead
children.definition: (especially of roads, paths, doors, signs, etc.) used to say where a path, wire etc goes or what place is on the other side of a door
examples: lead to/towards
The path led down to a small lake.
There's a track that leads directlytothe reservoir.
lead from/out of
the major artery leading from the heart
lead into/ onto
the door leading into the hallway
The French windows leadout ontoa wide shady terrace.
A narrow trail of blood led directlyintothe cave.
lead sb to/into sth
The riverside path leads visitors to a small chapel.
